message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Computational Models of Argument
Paper Abstract: Research into computational models of argument is a rich interdisciplinary field involving the study of natural, artificial and theoretical argumentation and requiring openness to interactions with a variety of disciplines, ranging from philosophy and cognitive science to formal logic and graph theory. The ultimate aim is to support the development of computer-based systems able to engage in argumentation-related activities, either with human users or among themselves. This book presents the proceedings of the sixth biennial International Conference on Computational Models of Argument (COMMA 2016), held in Potsdam, Germany, on 12- 16 September. The aim of the COMMA conferences is to bring together researchers interested in computational models of argument and the representation of argumentation structures in natural language texts, with special attention to contributions concerning emerging trends and the development of new connections with other areas. The book contains the 25 full papers, 17 short papers and 10 demonstration abstracts presented at the conference, together with 3 invited talks. Subjects covered include abstract, bipolar and structured argumentation, quantitative approaches and their connections with formalisms like Bayesian networks and fuzzy logic, multi-agent scenarios, algorithms and solvers, and mining arguments in text, dialogue, and social media. The book provides an overview of current research and developments in the field of computational models of argument, and will be essential reading for all those with an interest in the field.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Argumentation"

Links: [{"title":"Argumentation theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentation_theory"},{"title":"Argumentation framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentation_framework"},{"title":"Logic of argumentation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic_of_argumentation"},{"title":"Argumentation scheme - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentation_scheme"},{"title":"Term (argumentation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Term_(argumentation)"},{"title":"Talk:Argumentation ethics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Argumentation_ethics"},{"title":"Argumentation and Advocacy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentation_and_Advocacy"},{"title":"Centre for Research in Reasoning, Argumentation, and Rhetoric - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centre_for_Research_in_Reasoning,_Argumentation,_and_Rhetoric"},{"title":"Argument - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argument"},{"title":"Argument mining - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argument_mining"}]

Here are the search results for "Argumentation":

## Overview

Argumentation theory is the interdisciplinary study of how conclusions can be supported or undermined by premises through logical reasoning.(no content)With historical origins in logic, dialectic, and rhetoric, argumentation theory includes the arts and sciences of civil debate, dialogue, conversation, and persuasion.

## Structure and Key Elements

An argument is one or more premises—sentences, statements, or propositions—directed towards arriving at a logical conclusion.(no content)The purpose of an argument is to give reasons for one's thinking and understanding via justification, explanation, or persuasion.

## Types of Dialogue

Argumentation includes various forms of dialogue such as deliberation and negotiation which are concerned with collaborative decision-making procedures. It also encompasses eristic dialogue, the branch of social debate in which victory over an opponent is the primary goal, and didactic dialogue used for teaching.

## Applications

Argumentation is a daily occurrence, such as in public debate, science, and law. Additionally, argument mining is the automatic extraction and identification of argumentative structures from natural language text with the aid of computer programs. Such argumentative structures include the premise, conclusions, the argument scheme and the relationship between the main and subsidiary argument, or the main and counter-argument within discourse.

Web search results for query: "Cognitive science"

Links: [{"title":"Cognitive science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_science"},{"title":"Category:Cognitive science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Cognitive_science"},{"title":"List of cognitive scientists - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_cognitive_scientists"},{"title":"MIT Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MIT_Department_of_Brain_and_Cognitive_Sciences"},{"title":"Category:Cognitive science journals - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Cognitive_science_journals"},{"title":"Index of cognitive science articles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Index_of_cognitive_science_articles"},{"title":"Embodied cognitive science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Embodied_cognitive_science"},{"title":"Bayesian cognitive science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayesian_cognitive_science"},{"title":"Cognitive musicology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_musicology"},{"title":"Cognitive poetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_poetics"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about cognitive science:

## Definition and Overview

Cognitive science is the interdisciplinary, scientific study of the mind and its processes.(no content)It examines the nature, the tasks, and the functions of cognition.(no content)Mental faculties of concern to cognitive scientists include perception, memory, attention, reasoning, and language.

## Interdisciplinary Nature

Cognitive science is an interdisciplinary field with contributors from various fields, including psychology, neuroscience, linguistics, philosophy of mind, computer science, anthropology and biology.(no content)Cognitive scientists work collectively in hope of understanding the mind and its interactions with the surrounding world much like other sciences do. The field regards itself as compatible with the physical sciences and uses the scientific method as well as simulation or modeling.

## Historical Development

The modern culture of cognitive science can be traced back to the early cyberneticists in the 1930s and 1940s, such as Warren McCulloch and Walter Pitts, who sought to understand the organizing principles of the mind.(no content)The term cognitive science was coined by Christopher Longuet-Higgins in his 1973 commentary on the Lighthill report.

## Academic Establishment

The founding meeting of the Cognitive Science Society was held at the University of California, San Diego in 1979, which resulted in cognitive science becoming an internationally visible enterprise.(no content)In 1986, the first Cognitive Science Department in the world was founded at the University of California, San Diego.

Web search results for query: "Formal logic"

Links: [{"title":"Category:Systems of formal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Systems_of_formal_logic"},{"title":"Logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic"},{"title":"Notre Dame Journal of Formal Logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Notre_Dame_Journal_of_Formal_Logic"},{"title":"Term logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Term_logic"},{"title":"Mathematical logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_logic"},{"title":"Formal proof - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_proof"},{"title":"Dialectical logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dialectical_logic"},{"title":"Logic and dialectic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic_and_dialectic"},{"title":"Theory (mathematical logic) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theory_(mathematical_logic)"},{"title":"Glossary of logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glossary_of_logic"}]

Here are the search results for **Formal Logic**:

## Definition

Formal logic is the study of deductively valid inferences or logical truths. It examines how conclusions follow from premises based on the structure of arguments alone, independent of their topic and content.

## Key Characteristics

Formal logic, also known as symbolic logic, is widely used in mathematical logic. It uses a formal approach to study reasoning by replacing concrete expressions with abstract symbols to examine the logical form of arguments independent of their concrete content. It is topic-neutral since it is only concerned with the abstract structure of arguments and not with their concrete content.(no content)Formal logic is interested in deductively valid arguments, for which the truth of their premises ensures the truth of their conclusion. This means that it is impossible for the premises to be true and the conclusion to be false.

## Formal Systems and Languages

Formal logic uses formal languages to express, analyze, and clarify arguments. They normally have a very limited vocabulary and exact syntactic rules. These rules specify how their symbols can be combined to construct sentences, so-called well-formed formulas.

## Major Systems

The most commonly used system is classical logic. It consists of propositional logic and first-order logic.

## Historical Development

Modern formal logic has its roots in the work of late 19th-century mathematicians such as Gottlob Frege.

Links: [{"title":"Category:Systems of formal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Systems_of_formal_logic"},{"title":"Logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic"},{"title":"Notre Dame Journal of Formal Logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Notre_Dame_Journal_of_Formal_Logic"},{"title":"Term logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Term_logic"},{"title":"Mathematical logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_logic"},{"title":"Formal proof - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_proof"},{"title":"Dialectical logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dialectical_logic"},{"title":"Logic and dialectic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic_and_dialectic"},{"title":"Theory (mathematical logic) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theory_(mathematical_logic)"},{"title":"Glossary of logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glossary_of_logic"}]

Here are the search results for **Formal Logic**:

## Definition

Formal logic is the study of deductively valid inferences or logical truths. It examines how conclusions follow from premises based on the structure of arguments alone, independent of their topic and content.

## Key Characteristics

Formal logic, also known as symbolic logic, is widely used in mathematical logic. It uses a formal approach to study reasoning by replacing concrete expressions with abstract symbols to examine the logical form of arguments independent of their concrete content. It is topic-neutral since it is only concerned with the abstract structure of arguments and not with their concrete content.(no content)Formal logic is interested in deductively valid arguments, for which the truth of their premises ensures the truth of their conclusion. This means that it is impossible for the premises to be true and the conclusion to be false.

## Formal Systems and Languages

Formal logic uses formal languages to express, analyze, and clarify arguments. They normally have a very limited vocabulary and exact syntactic rules. These rules specify how their symbols can be combined to construct sentences, so-called well-formed formulas.

## Major Systems

The most commonly used system is classical logic. It consists of propositional logic and first-order logic.

## Historical Development

Modern formal logic has its roots in the work of late 19th-century mathematicians such as Gottlob Frege.

Web search results for query: "Multi-agent systems"

Links: [{"title":"Category:Multi-agent systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multi-agent_systems"},{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Distributed multi-agent reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_multi-agent_reasoning_system"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"},{"title":"Template:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"// - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jason_(multi-agent_systems_development_platform)"},{"title":"Java Agent Development Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_Agent_Development_Framework"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"}]

## Search Results: Multi-agent Systems

Here's what I found about multi-agent systems:

### Definition
A multi-agent system (MAS or "self-organized system") is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.

### Key Capabilities
Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

### Components and Characteristics
Multi-agent systems consist of agents and their environment. Typically multi-agent systems research refers to software agents. However, the agents in a multi-agent system could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.(no content)Agents have autonomy—they are at least partially independent, self-aware, autonomous—and the systems demonstrate decentralization where no agent is designated as controlling.

### Modern Developments
With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

### Applications
Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

### Related Field
Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is a sub-field of reinforcement learning. It focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment.

Links: [{"title":"Graph theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_theory"},{"title":"Tree (graph theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tree_(graph_theory)"},{"title":"Spectral graph theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectral_graph_theory"},{"title":"Star (graph theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_(graph_theory)"},{"title":"Rank (graph theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rank_(graph_theory)"},{"title":"Neighbourhood (graph theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neighbourhood_(graph_theory)"},{"title":"Path (graph theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Path_(graph_theory)"},{"title":"Distance (graph theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distance_(graph_theory)"},{"title":"Matching (graph theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matching_(graph_theory)"},{"title":"Homeomorphism (graph theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homeomorphism_(graph_theory)"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about graph theory:

## Overview

In mathematics and computer science, graph theory is the study of graphs, which are mathematical structures used to model pairwise relations between objects.(no content)A graph in this context is made up of vertices (also called nodes or points) which are connected by edges (also called arcs, links or lines).

## Historical Background

The paper written by Leonhard Euler on the Seven Bridges of Königsberg and published in 1736 is regarded as the first paper in the history of graph theory.

## Applications

Graph theory has diverse applications across many fields:

- **Chemistry and Physics**: In chemistry a graph makes a natural model for a molecule, where vertices represent atoms and edges bonds.
- **Linguistics**: Graph-theoretic methods, in various forms, have proven particularly useful in linguistics, since natural language often lends itself well to discrete structure. Traditionally, syntax and compositional semantics follow tree-based structures.
- **Biology**: In biology and conservation efforts a vertex can represent regions where certain species exist (or inhabit) and the edges represent migration paths or movement between the regions.
- **Social Networks**: Graph theory is also widely used in sociology as a way, for example, to measure actors' prestige or to explore rumor spreading, notably through the use of social network analysis software.
- **Navigation**: Weighted graphs are commonly used to program GPS's, and travel-planning search engines that compare flight times and costs.

Zadeh - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lotfi_A._Zadeh"}]

Here's an overview of fuzzy logic based on the search results:

## Definition

Fuzzy logic is a form of many-valued logic in which the truth value of variables may be any real number between 0 and 1.(no content)It is employed to handle the concept of partial truth, where the truth value may range between completely true and completely false. This contrasts with Boolean logic, where the truth values of variables may only be the integer values 0 or 1.

## History

The term fuzzy logic was introduced with the 1965 proposal of fuzzy set theory by mathematician Lotfi Zadeh. However, basic fuzzy logic had been studied since the 1920s, as infinite-valued logic—notably by Łukasiewicz and Tarski.

## Foundational Concept

Fuzzy logic is based on the observation that people make decisions based on imprecise and non-numerical information.(no content)Fuzzy models or fuzzy sets are mathematical means of representing vagueness and imprecise information (hence the term fuzzy).

## Applications

Fuzzy logic has been applied to many fields, from control theory to artificial intelligence.(no content)Fuzzy logic is used in control systems to allow experts to contribute vague rules such as "if you are close to the destination station and moving fast, increase the train's brake pressure"; these vague rules can then be numerically refined within the system.

Web search results for query: "Dialogue system"

Links: [{"title":"Dialogue system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dialogue_system"},{"title":"Dialogue Concerning the Two Chief World Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dialogue_Concerning_the_Two_Chief_World_Systems"},{"title":"Spoken dialog system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spoken_dialog_system"},{"title":"Issue-based information system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Issue-based_information_system"},{"title":"Sustained Dialogue Institute - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sustained_Dialogue_Institute"},{"title":"System (typeface) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/System_(typeface)"},{"title":"Production sound mixer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Production_sound_mixer"},{"title":"Theophilus Metcalfe - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theophilus_Metcalfe"},{"title":"Racial polarization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Racial_polarization"},{"title":"Castle Shikigami 2 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shikigami_No_Shiro_II"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about dialogue systems:

## Definition

A dialogue system, or conversational agent (CA), is a computer system intended to converse with a human.

## Communication Modes

Dialogue systems employ one or more of text, speech, graphics, haptics, gestures, and other modes for communication on both the input and output channel.

## Key Components

Principal to any dialogue system is the dialogue manager, which is a component that manages the state of the dialogue, and dialogue strategy.(no content)The semantic information is analysed by the dialogue manager, which keeps the history and state of the dialogue and manages the general flow of the conversation. Usually, the dialogue manager contacts one or more task managers, that have knowledge of the specific task domain.

## Historical Background

Those first systems were used in the telecom industry to provide phone various services in specific domains, e.g. automated agenda and train tables service.

## Modern Applications

Dialogue systems can support a broad range of applications in business enterprises, education, government, healthcare, and entertainment.(no content)Simple dialogue systems are widely used to decrease the human workload in call centers. In this and other industrial telephony applications, the functionality provided by dialogue systems is known as interactive voice response or IVR.

## Recent Developments

In the 2020s, dialogue systems have increasingly been built on top of large language models (LLMs), which allow them to handle open-domain conversation more flexibly than earlier rule-based or statistical approaches.(no content)Modern implementations often integrate both voice and text interfaces, providing users with multi-modal interaction through conversational agents.

Links: [{"title":"Bayesian network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayesian_network"},{"title":"Variable-order Bayesian network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Variable-order_Bayesian_network"},{"title":"Category:Bayesian networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Bayesian_networks"},{"title":"Talk:Bayesian network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Bayesian_network"},{"title":"Dynamic Bayesian network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_Bayesian_network"},{"title":"Bayesian networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Bayesian_networks&redirect=no"},{"title":"Bayesian programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayesian_programming"},{"title":"Neural network Gaussian process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network_Gaussian_process"},{"title":"Dependency network (graphical model) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dependency_network_(graphical_model)"},{"title":"Ann Nicholson - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ann_Nicholson"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of Bayesian networks:

## Overview

Bayesian networks are a modeling tool for assigning probabilities to events, and thereby characterizing the uncertainty in a model's predictions.(no content)A Bayesian network can be considered a mechanism for automatically applying Bayes' theorem to complex problems.

## Key Functionality

Because a Bayesian network is a complete model for its variables and their relationships, it can be used to answer probabilistic queries about them. For example, the network can be used to update knowledge of the state of a subset of variables when other variables (the evidence variables) are observed. This process of computing the posterior distribution of variables given evidence is called probabilistic inference.

## Structure and Development

Developing a Bayesian network often begins with creating a DAG (directed acyclic graph) such that variables satisfy the local Markov property with respect to the graph. The conditional probability distributions of each variable given its parents in the graph are assessed.

## Inference Methods

The most common exact inference methods are: variable elimination, which eliminates (by integration or summation) the non-observed non-query variables one by one by distributing the sum over the product; clique tree propagation, which caches the computation so that many variables can be queried at one time and new evidence can be propagated quickly; and recursive conditioning and AND/OR search.

## Related Variations

A dynamic Bayesian network (DBN) is a Bayesian network which relates variables to each other over adjacent time steps.

Links: [{"title":"Text mining - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Text_mining"},{"title":"List of text mining methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_text_mining_methods"},{"title":"National Centre for Text Mining - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Centre_for_Text_Mining"},{"title":"List of text mining software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_text_mining_software"},{"title":"Category:Text mining - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Text_mining"},{"title":"Document clustering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Document_clustering"}]

Here are the search results for "Text mining":

## Overview

Text mining, also known as text data mining (TDM) or text analytics, is the process of deriving high-quality information from text.(no content)It involves "the discovery by computer of new, previously unknown information, by automatically extracting information from different written resources."(no content)Written resources may include websites, books, emails, reviews, and articles.

## Process and Techniques

Text mining usually involves the process of structuring the input text (usually parsing, along with the addition of some derived linguistic features and the removal of others, and subsequent insertion into a database), deriving patterns within the structured data, and finally evaluation and interpretation of the output.(no content)Typical text mining tasks include text categorization, text clustering, concept/entity extraction, production of granular taxonomies, sentiment analysis, document summarization, and entity relation modeling (i.e., learning relations between named entities).

## Goals and Methods

The overarching goal is, essentially, to turn text into data for analysis, via the application of natural language processing (NLP), different types of algorithms and analytical methods.(no content)High-quality information is typically obtained by devising patterns and trends by means such as statistical pattern learning.

## Applications

A typical application is to scan a set of documents written in a natural language and either model the document set for predictive classification purposes or populate a database or search index with the information extracted.

Web search results for query: "Algorithm"

Links: [{"title":"Algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorithm"},{"title":"A* search algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A*_search_algorithm"},{"title":"In-place algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/In-place_algorithm"},{"title":"List of algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_algorithms"},{"title":"Introduction to Algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Introduction_to_Algorithms"},{"title":"Dijkstra's algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dijkstra's_algorithm"},{"title":"Greedy algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greedy_algorithm"},{"title":"Euclidean algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euclidean_algorithm"},{"title":"Shor's algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shor's_algorithm"},{"title":"Symmetric-key algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetric-key_algorithm"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about algorithms:

## Definition

In mathematics and computer science, an algorithm is a finite sequence of mathematically rigorous instructions, typically used to solve a class of specific problems or to perform a computation.(no content)Algorithms are used as specifications for performing calculations and data processing.

## How Algorithms Work

Starting from an initial state and initial input (perhaps empty), the instructions describe a computation that, when executed, proceeds through a finite number of well-defined successive states, eventually producing "output" and terminating at a final ending state.

## Characteristics

More advanced algorithms can use conditionals to divert the code execution through various routes (referred to as automated decision-making) and deduce valid inferences (referred to as automated reasoning).(no content)Some algorithms, known as randomized algorithms, incorporate random input.

## Historical Background

The earliest evidence of algorithms is found in ancient Mesopotamian mathematics. A Sumerian clay tablet found in Shuruppak near Baghdad and dated to c. 2500 BC describes the earliest division algorithm.

The word "algorithm" itself has interesting origins. Around 825 AD, Persian scientist and polymath Muḥammad ibn Mūsā al-Khwārizmī wrote books on Hindu arithmetic, and in the early 12th century, Latin translations of these texts appeared.

## Implementation

Most algorithms are intended to be implemented as computer programs. However, algorithms are also implemented by other means, such as in a biological neural network (for example, the human brain performing arithmetic or an insect looking for food), in an electrical circuit, or a mechanical device.

Links: [{"title":"Argument mining - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argument_mining"},{"title":"Argument technology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argument_technology"},{"title":"Category:Argument technology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Argument_technology"},{"title":"Araucaria (software) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Araucaria_(software)"},{"title":"Argument (linguistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verb_argument"},{"title":"Argüman - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arg%C3%BCman"},{"title":"Argumentation theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentation_theory"},{"title":"Argument Web - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argument_web"},{"title":"Anthracite coal strike of 1902 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthracite_coal_strike_of_1902"},{"title":"Italian Hall disaster - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_Hall_disaster"}]

## Overview

Argument mining, or argumentation mining, is a research area within the natural-language processing field.(no content)The goal of argument mining is the automatic extraction and identification of argumentative structures from natural language text with the aid of computer programs.

## Applications

Argument mining has been used to provide students individual writing support by accessing and visualizing the argumentation discourse in their texts, and application of argument mining in a user-centered learning tool helped students improve their argumentation skills significantly compared to traditional argumentation learning applications.

## Challenges

Given the wide variety of text genres and the different research perspectives and approaches, it has been difficult to reach a common and objective evaluation scheme, and many annotated data sets have been proposed, with some gaining popularity, but a consensual data set is yet to be found.

## Related Field

Argument mining is part of the broader field of argument technology. The Workshop on Argument Mining has run annually since 2014, reflecting the growing importance of this research area.

Links: [{"title":"Argumentation theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentation_theory"},{"title":"Argument (linguistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argument_(linguistics)"},{"title":"Argument map - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argument_map"},{"title":"Argüman - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arg%C3%BCman"},{"title":"Argumentation scheme - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentation_scheme"},{"title":"Argumentation framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentation_framework"},{"title":"Argument - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argument"},{"title":"Argument technology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argument_technology"},{"title":"Argument mining - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argument_mining"},{"title":"Gish gallop - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gish_gallop"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about structured argumentation:

## Overview

Argumentation theory is the interdisciplinary study of how conclusions can be supported or undermined by premises through logical reasoning, with historical origins in logic, dialectic, and rhetoric.

## Core Structure

An argument has one or more premises and one conclusion.(no content)Argumentation theory focuses on how logical reasoning leads to end results through an internal structure built of premises, a method of reasoning and a conclusion.

## Key Components and Methods

**Argumentation Schemes**: An argumentation scheme is a template that represents a common type of argument used in ordinary conversation, with each onepresenting a type of connection between premises and a conclusion in an argument.

**Argument Mapping**: An argument map is a visual representation of the structure of an argument that typically includes all the key components of the argument, traditionally called the conclusion and the premises.(no content)Such visual diagrams facilitate diagrammatic reasoning and promote one's ability to grasp and to make sense of information rapidly and readily, and can provide structured, semi-formal frameworks for representing arguments using interactive visual language.

**Argumentation Frameworks**: In artificial intelligence and related fields, an argumentation framework is a way to deal with contentious information and draw conclusions from it using formalized arguments.

## Applications

Douglas N. Walton developed a distinctive philosophical theory of logical argumentation built around a set of practical methods to help a user identify, analyze and evaluate arguments in everyday conversational discourse and in more structured areas such as debate, law and scientific fields.(no content)Argument maps are useful not only for representing and analyzing existing writings, but also for thinking through issues as part of a problem-structuring process, and the use of such argument analysis for thinking through issues has been called "reflective argumentation".

Argumentation theory is the interdisciplinary study of how conclusions can be supported or undermined by premises through logical reasoning, with historical origins in logic, dialectic, and rhetoric.

## Core Structure

An argument has one or more premises and one conclusion.(no content)Argumentation theory focuses on how logical reasoning leads to end results through an internal structure built of premises, a method of reasoning and a conclusion.

## Key Components and Methods

**Argumentation Schemes**: An argumentation scheme is a template that represents a common type of argument used in ordinary conversation, with each onepresenting a type of connection between premises and a conclusion in an argument.

**Argument Mapping**: An argument map is a visual representation of the structure of an argument that typically includes all the key components of the argument, traditionally called the conclusion and the premises.(no content)Such visual diagrams facilitate diagrammatic reasoning and promote one's ability to grasp and to make sense of information rapidly and readily, and can provide structured, semi-formal frameworks for representing arguments using interactive visual language.

**Argumentation Frameworks**: In artificial intelligence and related fields, an argumentation framework is a way to deal with contentious information and draw conclusions from it using formalized arguments.

## Applications

Douglas N. Walton developed a distinctive philosophical theory of logical argumentation built around a set of practical methods to help a user identify, analyze and evaluate arguments in everyday conversational discourse and in more structured areas such as debate, law and scientific fields.(no content)Argument maps are useful not only for representing and analyzing existing writings, but also for thinking through issues as part of a problem-structuring process, and the use of such argument analysis for thinking through issues has been called "reflective argumentation".
